description.narrative: The Africa Regional Programme (ARP) 3 Phase 2 ran from 2014 to 2017. It was implemented in ten countries in Africa namely, Botswana, Burundi, Cote d'Ivoire, Kenya, Senegal, South Africa, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. The intervention was an extension of the work done by the International HIV/AIDS Alliance (IHAA) in previous iterations of the ARP, but with an increased emphasis on KPs. The programme transitioned from directly funding mainly project-based work of Linking Organisation’s (LOs) programmes to a longer-term, building of LO’s organisational and technical capacity to respond to the needs of KPs. This shift was underpinned by the need for sustainability: in order to consolidate the achievements of phase 1, KP programming and KP advocacy work needed to be integrated into the core ongoing and future mainstream work of the LOs. The intervention's specific objectives were: 1. Improved technical capacity among civil society organisations to promote KP access to HIV, health and rights services, by end of 2017.2. In at least 6 countries, the Alliance can demonstrate increased engagement of national policy makers in KP issues3. Improved processes for regional knowledge sharing and learning by LOs and KP CSO, by 2017. By design, the intervention was meant to be flexible and respond to realities in the different contexts. In this regard, the results achieved over time are quite varied across the participating countries. In Botswana, the Botswana Network on Ethics, Law and HIV (BONELA), the participating LO, had established itself as a leading provider of HIV prevention services and commodities for people engaged in transactional sex and MSM. The organisation created safe spaces for these KPs which also served as drop-in centres for psychosocial support and HIV testing services. It contributed to the growth of the LGBTI movement in the country and was part of the court process that led to the 2016 landmark ruling allowing the registration of an LGBTI organisation as an independent entity. In Burundi, the LO (ABS) remained active despite the political crisis in the country that broke out in 2015. It implemented REAct, an IHAA tool and methodology used to document and respond to human rights violations of KPs, and trained key stakeholders on human rights and health matters. This resulted in reduced stigmatisation of KPs and significant improvements in access to health services. In 2016, a referral strategy between CSOs and selected health care facilities was adopted to enhance access by KPs. The support provided to ANS, the LO in Cote d'Ivoire, contributed to the improved articulation of KP issues in the organisation's strategic documents and programmes. For instance, the revised capacity-building sessions with religious leaders led to more inclusion of non-stigmatisation discussions in their engagement with congregants. Over the years, there were also some unintended results achieved. For instance, the Looking In-Looking Out (LILO) reflective process aimed at building an individual's psychological resilience as a way of bringing about individual and community transformation was assessed to achieve more than what was initially thought. The process was observed to be a useful intervention for influencing how people and organisations exposed to it think about programme design and about change and development interventions in general. In addition to attitudinal change towards KPs, LILO appeared to contribute towards improvements in staff relationships, leadership skills, facilitation practice, and organisational focus towards KP rights.
